abstract.text: Automatically and transparently convert accounts to Sign in with Apple or to use strong passwords for improved security.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

metadata.title: Upgrading Account Security With an Account Authentication Modification Extension

inlineContent.text: When accounts have weak, easily guessed passwords, or if an account is breached, the iOS Security Recommendations help users update account passwords. Adding an Account Authentication Modification Extension to your app lets users easily switch to a strong, complex password, or upgrade to Sign in with Apple. The experience for users is simple and painless, often only requiring the tap of a button.
You configure your extension to support upgrading to strong passwords, upgrading to Sign in with Apple, or both. Users initiate upgrades from the following places:
In Settings > Passwords, when viewing a security recommendation.
In your app, when the user signs in to their account using a weak or breached password.
In your app, using a dedicated interface you implement.
If your account security policy requires additional steps, such as two-factor authentication, your extension can include these steps in the upgrade process.

To upgrade user accounts stored in the iOS password manager, you must first establish an association between your app and the domains that to which your account belongs. To make this association, add an associated domain file to your website that includes a
entry, and configure a matching
. For more information about how to configure associated domains, see

content.text: Add an Account Authentication Modification Extension to Your App

inlineContent.text: Xcode provides a starting point to create your extension. To add the Account Authentication Modification extension to your project:
Open your app project in Xcode and choose File > New > Target.
From the Application Extension group, select Account Authentication, and then click Next.
Enter the name of your extension.
Click Finish.
Your extension’s
file specifies the types of upgrades your app supports. To support upgrading weak passwords to strong passwords, set the
key to
. To support upgrading accounts from using passwords to using Sign in with Apple, set the
to
When the system begins a strong password upgrade, it generates a new strong password. If the system-generated password doesn’t meet your needs, optionally add the
key with a string value that describes your requirements. For details about the format of this string, see
. Use the
to verify the passwords the system generates with your requirements.

When the user initiates a strong password upgrade, the system invokes your extension to perform the upgrade. To perform a one-tap automatic upgrade to strong passwords, the system loads your extension and instantiates a subclass of
. The system calls the
method you implement in the view controller.

inlineContent.text: This method receives the following parameters:
An
to identify the service to update, for example a website account.

To perform the automatic upgrade, the extension communicates with your server to authorize and perform the upgrade. Use the current password, existing token, or credential information from your app to confirm with your server that the user is authorized to perform the password upgrade. Once the server confirms the user authorization, send the new password to your server to perform the upgrade. If the system-generated password doesn’t satisfy your server’s requirements, you can use a different password than the one the system provides.
After completing the password change on your server, call
on the view controller’s
, passing the new credential for the service. The system stores the new credential in the Keychain, and removes the old credential.
If the user isn’t authorized to perform the upgrade, or the update fails, cancel the request as follows:

content.text: Support Automatic Upgrades to Sign in with Apple

inlineContent.text: The steps to implement automatic upgrades to Sign in with Apple are very similar to the ones to upgrade to a strong password. To support upgrading to Sign in with Apple, your app must support Sign in with Apple. For more information, see
and
When the user initiates an upgrade to Sign in with Apple, the system loads your extension, and invokes the
method of your view controller.
This method receives the following parameters:
An
that identifies the service to update, for example a website account.
The service’s current password.
A user-info dictionary that contains app-specific information, if your app initiates the request.
Use the current password to authorize with your server that the user can perform the upgrade. If not, fail the request as described above.
To perform the upgrade, request the Sign in with Apple credentials from the extensionContext by calling
. If the system provides a Sign in with Apple credential, send the credential information to your server, and then complete the request by calling
. Once complete, the system removes the old password from the Keychain.

inlineContent.text: To create the Sign in with Apple credential, the system prompts the user and communicates with Apple. If the user cancels the request, the system calls the completion handler with an error that specifies a

code. In that case, cancel the request using the same error code and no failure reason, and don’t show any additional user interface. If the device can’t communicate with Apple’s servers, the completion handler may be passed
credentials. In this case, cancel the request with an error that specifies
as the error code.

content.text: Perform Upgrades With Additional Security Requirements

inlineContent.text: If the user initiates an account authentication upgrade but you require additional security steps, such as using two-factor authentication, fail the initial automatic request with an error that specifies user interaction is required.
The system initiates a new request that includes presenting the view controller’s view by calling either
or
, depending on the type of the original request. Configure your view controller’s view appropriately for the request and return from the method.

After your method returns, the system presents your view controller’s view with a system-provided navigation bar, including a cancel button. Once the system presents the view, guide the user through performing the additional steps. When the user completes the steps, continue the upgrade process. For a strong password upgrade, commit the new strong password, provided in the original request, to your server. For an upgrade to Sign in with Apple, call
to request a new Sign in with Apple credential as described earlier.
If the user fails to complete the additional steps, or the upgrade fails for any other reason, call
to cancel the request as described in earlier examples. The system dismisses the view controller’s view.
If the user taps the system-provided cancel button, the system dismisses the interface and calls your view controller’s
method. If you need to perform any cleanup work, override this method and call the superclass
method to complete the process.

content.text: Initiate Security Upgrades From Within Your App

inlineContent.text: To initiate upgrades to strong passwords or to use Sign in with Apple from within your app, use the
class.
When your app initiates an upgrade request, the work your extension does is the same as the previous sections describe. To configure the request, instantiate either an
or
object, passing the following parameters:
The user name for the user’s account.
An
to identify the service to update, for example a website account.
A user info dictionary that contains any authentication information the extension needs.
Unlike the system-initiated upgrades, your extension doesn’t receive an existing password in the calls to
or
. If your extension needs existing password or authentication information to perform the authorization with your server, include it in the user info dictionary.

abstract.text: Make it easy for users to log into apps and services.
An object that performs a request to modify an account’s authentication properties.
Performs a request to upgrade the authentication credentials for an account to a strong password, or to use Sign in with Apple.
An object that provides a presentation context for the account modification request’s user interface.
An interface you implement for receiving success and failure statuses about modification of an account’s authentication properties.
Tells the delegate an account modification request failed.
Tells the delegate an account modification request completed successfully.
An interface you implement to coordinate presentation of the user interface when modifying an account’s authentication properties.
An object that you interact with to change an account’s password or to upgrade to Sign in with Apple.
Cancels a request with an error.
Completes a request to update an account’s authentication credentials from using a weak password to using a strong password.
Completes the process of upgrading an account’s authentication credentials from using passwords to using Sign in with Apple.
Retrieves the user’s current Sign in with Apple authorization credentials.
A request to upgrade from using a password to using Sign in with Apple.
A request to automatically upgrade from a weak password to a strong password.
A view controller that can upgrade user passwords to strong passwords, or convert accounts to use Sign in with Apple.
Cancels a request that the user initiated.
Upgrades a user’s weak password to a strong password.
Converts an account’s authentication mechanism from using passwords to using Sign in with Apple.
The context your account authentication modification extension uses to provide information to the system.
Prepares the view controller’s interface that displays when upgrading from a weak password to a strong password.
Prepares the view controller’s interface that displays when converting an account that uses password authentication to use Sign in with Apple.
An identifier representing a particular service for which the user needs a credential, like a web site.
The operation failed.
The user canceled the operation.
Provide a way for users of your app to set up an account and start using your services.

abstract.text: The associated domains for specific services, such as shared web credentials, universal links, and App Clips.
The rules the system satisfies when generating a strong password for your extension during an automatic upgrade.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the extension supports upgrading a user’s password to a strong password.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the extension supports upgrading from using password authentication to using Sign in with Apple.
Modify the strong password rules for your app by adding your own restrictions.
Connect your app and a website to provide both a native app and a browser experience.
Defines the `id` of a null instance.
